May 19

Exploring PEI

No comments yet

Recently, myself, Ann (my wife) and driver Dave and his wife, Martha, hit the road to check out some new tours for 2016.

Leaving from Halifax, we headed towards Truro and the Millbrook Cultural and Heritage Centre. The Centre offers an innovative multimedia presentation of the rich history of the Mi’kmaw people, however, today it was closed so we continued on to Aulac, NB and turned off for the Confederation Bridge.

View of Confederation Bridge from Cape Jourimain

We briefly stopped at Cape Journiman to photograph the bridge. “The curved, 12.9 kilometre (8 mile) long bridge isthe longest in the world crossing ice-covered water, and more than a decade after its construction, it endures as one of Canada’s top engineering achievements of the 20th century”.

We stopped at Gateway Village – a picturesque shopping spot – gathered our maps and coffee and set off to explore Prince Edward Island.

Our first stop was at Seven Mile Bay so we could photograph the sheer immensity of the Confederation Bridge – truly a spectacular sight!

View of Bridge from Seven Mile Bay

Spring planting

We toured along Routes 1, 1A and 2 to Hunter River, passing tens of thousands of acres of freshly plowed farm land being prepared for potatoes, corn or soybean. Generally speaking, this was the constant scene as we toured around PEI – freshly plowed landscape.  No doubt this land will be vibrant and colourful in a few months.

Many of the PEI ‘tourist’ spots were closed (such as New Glasgow Lobster Dinner restaurant and PEI Preserves) but will shortly open for the season.

Our overnight accommodation was at Brackley Beach North Winds Resort with hosts Isaac MacPherson and his Father, Murray – Thanks Guys!

Just after we checked into the North Winds, I spied a FOX on the grounds!  PEI was famous for Silver Fox Farming but when those furs went of fashion, the fox farmers opened the cages and released their foxes into the “wild”, so it is not uncommon to see them.  As we returned from dinner we saw another fox along the side of the road – foxes, it appears, prefer chicken to rabbit …according to Dave who knows these things.

We headed for Charlottetown for dinner and ate at Papa Joe’s on University Avenue.

In the morning, following a great breakfast (thank you Isaac), Dave and I met with Mickey from Red Sand Tours.  We hope his team will be joining Blue Diamond Tours for shore excursions from Charlottetown.

After our check-out, we headed eastward towards Souris.   Souris is a Canadian port town in northeastern Kings County, Prince Edward Island. It’s located in an area famous for its beaches and potatoes (and amazing scenery), containing the majority of Prince Edward Island’s potato farmers.  

 We stopped in St Peters for photos – what a beautiful community!  We ultimately arrived at The Inn at Bay Fortune, owned by chef Michael Smith and his wife Charity.  We met and spoke with Charity who was excited to announce they have earned their 5 stars for this year.  (We have included this inn and their “feast” as part BDT’s Culinary Delights Tour).

Inn at Bay Fortune

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

View from Inn

Near the inn is the Government wharf – a super place to see boats and people landing their catches.

Bay of Fortune Wharf

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

We briefly stopped in Souris and explored the terminal for the ferry to Ile de la Madeleine (a five hour crossing one way) and the nearby lighthouse before heading back to Charlottetown.

Grape vines for Brandy

At Rollo Bay we stopped at “The Myriad View Artisan Distillery” and toured their vineyard.  Their grapes used for making “Brandy” – no wine here.  The distillery tour, I was told, takes about 15 minutes more or less and it’s free.  We couldn’t help but buy a product sample!   Arriving in Charlottetown, we lunched on the city’s waterfront, “Lobster on the Wharf “.

Lobster Lunch

Lobster on the wharf

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

After lunch, we enjoyed a brief tour through Charlottetown, drove through UPEI campus and then onto Route 2 to Hunter River and Kensington.  We continued on to Summerside then back to Gateway Village for our return journey to Halifax.

May 16

The CSS Tallahassee

No comments yet

 

Boardwalk at Fishermans Cove

Ann and I spent some exploring Fisherman’s Cove and the surrounding area. This is where the CSS Tallahassee performed an extraordinary feat through this narrow waterway to escape from Halifax during the US Civil war.  This is part of the story as told by the Maritime Museum of the Atlantic:

Under cover of darkness, August 19, 1864, the Confederate raider CSS Tallahassee slipped through Halifax Harbour’s Eastern Passage under the skilled pilotage of Jock Flemming. This act of both skilled seamanship and daring entered our Maritime history and became legend.

The Tallahassee Affair

The effects of the American Civil War extended far beyond the boundaries of the United States. Throughout Europe and British North America, the populace was divided in its sympathies despite government avowals of neutrality. In Halifax, there was a strong sympathy for the cause of the Confederacy, especially among businessmen who profited from commercial dealings with the Confederate states.

At dawn on August 18th, 1864, The Confederate Steamship Tallahassee, a raider from Wilmington, North Carolina, steamed into Halifax Harbour in hopes of replenishing her dwindling supply of coal. Tallahassee’s job as a raider had been to attack Union commercial shipping and, in the month preceding, under the command of Capt. John Taylor Wood, she had sunk or bonded over 30 Union vessels.

Under the British Neutrality Laws, Tallahassee’s stay in Halifax was limited to 24 hours or enough time to take on sufficient coal at Woodside to enable her to return to Wilmington, the nearest “friendly” port. The Lt. Governor of Nova Scotia allowed a further 24 hours for Tallahassee to ship a new mainmast to replace the one she had lost in a collision a week before.

When Capt. Wood heard reports of Union gunboats waiting off the harbour entrance for Tallahassee to leave, he sought the advice of one of the senior harbour pilots, “Jock” Flemming, on how best to elude the enemy. It was decided to attempt the Eastern Passage, a feat never before accomplished by a vessel the size of Tallahassee. At 0100 on Saturday, August 20, Tallahassee weighed anchor and, after an hour of skillful maneuvering, cleared the Passage and headed for the open sea.

The daring of Captain Wood and the skill of Jock Flemming became legend in Nova Scotia long after the event and today, the Tallahassee School in Eastern Passage commemorates the event.

Apr 18

Spring Road Trip

No comments yet

What does a tour operator do on a day off? One of his own tours of course!

Blue Diamond Tours recently created “Cajun Motherland” single and multi-day trips, so my wife and I decided to leisurely drive the single day trip.

A beautiful spring day, high tides forecast…we couldn’t have asked for better weather and dramatic scenery.

Our itinerary took us through Wolfville, with a stop at Hennigar’s Farm Market for ice cream (Can anyone resist doing this?). Following our farm market purchases, we drove over to Port Williams, located on the Cornwallis River, for a couple quick ‘pics’ of the Acadian Dykes (circa 1650) which follow along the banks of this Fundy tidal river.

Our next stop was Planter’s Ridge Winery, located on a former New England Planter farm, but more formerly, an Acadian farmstead. Following a purchase of a bottle of Tidal Bay wines and more ‘pics’, we headed back towards Halifax.

As we crossed the Gaspereau River, the incoming tide had filled it to “the brim”, and later, as we crossed the Avon River marshes, they were almost totally covered by the incoming tide. Quite a spectacular sight!

In Windsor, we visited the Park’s Canada Fort Edward Site (blockhouse), a fortress whose history is intertwined with the Expulsion of the Acadians in 1755. Standing proudly and steeped in history, it was the perfect ending to a wonderful spring road trip!

Nov 09

Best Practice Mission

No comments yet

Blue Diamond Tours (really me, Bob) participated in a Best Practice Mission sponsored by TIANS and Tourism Nova Scotia

“The mission was to focus on the Atlantic coastline between St. Margaret’s Bay and Shelburne, this mission will provide participants with an inside look at how to develop effective grassroots partnerships and marketable product offerings. Delegates will learn how to enhance their regional inventory of quality tourism experiences and identify potential supporters and collaborators. The mission itinerary will encompass a broad array of tourism businesses and organizations that have competitively positioned themselves as a destination or experience of choice.”

I did learn a lot about a lot of things and have a couple of exciting partnership/collaborative opportunities in the works for 2016. I identified new experiences to incorporated in Blue Diamond Tours’ 2016 offerings (ie: marketable product offerings) on the South Shore, the Gold Coast (Eastern Shore) and Cape Breton.

Look for these in early 2016.

May 24

Baddeck in April

No comments yet

Alexander Graham Bell Meseum

Ann and I headed out for Baddeck ( of Alexander Graham Bell fame ) , Thursday April 24, about 9:45 am. Rain was our constant companion. Stopped for coffee and a quick snack at Antigonish’s McDonald’s.

At the Canso Causway, the rain stopped as we drove onto Cape Breton Island. As we reached the
Bras d’ Or ( TCH# 105) we immediately saw they were ice-bound. But, there were sections of the lakes that were clear of ice.

We checked into the Inverary Resort,Shore Drive, Baddeck about 2:00 pm — our room was spacious in the Main Lodge building.

Ann, has not visited Baddeck for quite awhile – so – it was tour-time. Stopped briefly at the Co-Op and loaded up on fruit, snacks, and sparkling water for later on. On Water Street, the tide was high, the wind was strong and the breakers were hitting over the sea-wall and ending up on parts of the street.

We briefly drove around the Bell Museum complex – not yet open and headed out for the Cabot Trail. Unfortunately the cable-ferry at Englishtown was not operating ( reason ice ): Saint Ann’s Bay was mostly ice covered, additionally the road to Goose Cove, had high banks of plowed snow, plus the fields were snow bound as well. It was a scenic drive but different to that of touring season. We turned around to returning to Baddeck.

Near Baddeck is Kildare Landing, a vacation home development , over-looking the Bras d’ Or. We drove in and looked around, it was quickly obvious, this is a very high quality complex . Even with our recent less than ideal weather, Kildare had about a dozen guests in residence.

For dinner, we tried the cafe ” Three Doors Down ” and were very happy with that decision. Great home-cooked real food. Later, we both decided that on a scale of 1 to 10 (10 being best ) our selections rated a 12.

Unfortunately, following breakfast and my business meeting, we headed back to Halifax but the sun was shining, it was +7C : a pleasant April day. But, reaching the mainland, the temp dropped to +2C and our thus enjoyed drizzle/ rain all the way to Truro.

Lunch stop was Mother Webb’s near Antigonish. Another winner meal-wise. I had been told, over the years, by a number of fellow travelers that Mother Webb’s was worth a stop and they were so correct. Good food, fast and friendly service ( clean rest-rooms too ), good pricing too.

Crossing Mount Thom, we experienced, ice covered trees ( temp down to +1C ) and ground that was free of snow on our drive to Baddeck was now covered with a skiff of fresh snow. It was only on arriving in Halifax that the temp hit the early morning readings of Baddeck – +7C., but no sun.
Kildare Landing — www.Capebretonlifestyles.com/aster
Mother Webb’s is a mere 661 miles north of Boston.

Apr 23

Halifax Public Gardens

No comments yet

Halifax Public Gardens

Here is another ‘not to be missed – special place’ during your Halifax visit.  Since 1836, Haligonians have taken great pride in our Halifax Public Gardens, the finest example of a Victorian-era heritage gardens conceived in the “Gardenesque Style” .

The “Gardens” cover 16 acres  in the center of Atlantic Canada’s largest City. With serpentine pathways and flower beds, a “tea- room”  (Horticultural Hall circa 1847); a bandstand  (circa 1887 – honouring Queen Victoria’s Golden Jubilee – restoration 2012); Jubilee and Soldiers Memorial Fountains, and Griffin’s Pond, part of ” Freshwater Stream ” that supplied HMS ships in the 1750’s . The aim was and still is, to provide a sensory cornucopia by displaying a great variety of plants in a confined space.

Come, visit, stroll the pathways, there is much to delight the eye; hear the song of bird; the gentle splash of a fountain; enjoy a warm breeze, spend time lounging on one of the many period benches scattered through the entire garden complex. After a time, you will leave inspired, invigorated and refreshed.

Blue Diamond Tours features the Halifax Public Gardens in many of our tours and excursions

Apr 23

The Frog Pond

No comments yet

Escape into nature’s tranquility on the outskirts of our vibrant urban city-life, by a short mini-hike, around the Frog Pond. Located on the western shore of the Northwest Arm. part of Sir Stanford Flemming Park.  This trail  is 1.4 klms long and takes about 30 minutes +/- to complete. It has hilly, level, wooden bridges sections and scenic vista’s through-out, as you traverse the pond.   Close to the Halifax’s core yet far enough to be in surrounded in/by nature.  Truly, another ‘hidden’ treasure of Halifax.

Blue Diamond will include this  “Halifax Gem” as part of your hiking excursion or incorporate a stroll as part of any other tours in/around Halifax

Apr 23

The Halifax Citadel

No comments yet

Halifax Citadel, Halifax, Nova Scotia

When the British founded the city in 1749, a strong feature from a defensive perspective was the high hill overlooking the harbour and it’s approaches. On this hill was constructed the central fortress for the defense of the new town and naval base, The Citadel.

Today’s Citadel is the fourth to occupy the location. The top of the hill was lowered some 40 to 70 feet through all the construction and leveling. The first fortification of any real permanence on the Hill was completed on 1761. The fortress as it is today was completed in 1856.

Many Blue Diamond Excursions tour and/or visit this not so hidden gem of Halifax

Old Stones from Exploration to Preservation

No comments yet

The Genealogical Association of Nova Scotia is presenting a six lecture sessions called “Old Stones: From Exploration to Preservation” May 24 and 25, 2014 at the Nova Scotia Agricultural College Campus, Truro, NS.  It includes a field trip to the historic Onslow Cemetery with poster displays and networking opportunities.  For more information about the conference and to recieve a registration packet contact Dawn Josey at info@novascotiaancestors.ca

An information package (PDF) is available for viewing or download. The schedule of speakers and a registration form are also available.
